google-compute-ssl-certificate.body:
resource "google_compute_ssl_certificate" "$1" {
    # private_key - (Required) Write only private key in PEM format.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    private_key = ""

    # certificate - (Required) A local certificate file in PEM format. The chain   may be at most 5 certs long, and must include at least one intermediate   cert. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    certificate = ""

    # name - (Optional) A unique name for the SSL certificate. If you leave this blank, Terraform will auto-generate a unique name.
    name = ""

    # name_prefix - (Optional) Creates a unique name beginning with the specified prefix. Conflicts with `name`.
    name_prefix = ""

    # description - (Optional) An optional description of this resource.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "certificate_id" - A unique ID for the certificate, assigned by GCE.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
}

For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/http/ssl-certificates) and

resource "google_compute_subnetwork" "$1" {
    # ip_cidr_range - (Required) The range of IP addresses belonging to this subnetwork secondary range. Ranges must be unique and non-overlapping with all primary and secondary IP ranges within a network. 
    ip_cidr_range = ""

    # range_name - (Required) The name associated with this subnetwork secondary range, used when adding an alias IP range to a VM instance.
    range_name = ""

    # network - (Required) The network name or resource link to the parent   network of this subnetwork. The parent network must have been created   in custom subnet mode.
    network = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # ip_cidr_range - (Required) The IP address range that machines in this   network are assigned to, represented as a CIDR block.
    ip_cidr_range = ""

    # description - (Optional) Description of this subnetwork.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region this subnetwork will be created in. If   unspecified, this defaults to the region configured in the provider.
    region = ""

    # private_ip_google_access - (Optional) Whether the VMs in this subnet   can access Google services without assigned external IP   addresses.
    private_ip_google_access = ""

    # secondary_ip_range - (Optional) (Optional, [Beta](/docs/providers/google/index.html#beta-features)) An array of configurations for secondary IP ranges for VM instances contained in this subnetwork. Structure is documented below.
    secondary_ip_range = ""

    # private_ip_google_access - (Optional) Whether the VMs in this subnet   can access Google services without assigned external IP   addresses.
    private_ip_google_access = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "gateway_address" - The IP address of the gateway.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
}

google-compute-target-pool.body:
resource "google_compute_target_pool" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE. Changing
    name = ""

    # backup_pool - (Optional) URL to the backup target pool. Must also set   failover\_ratio.
    backup_pool = ""

    # description - (Optional) Textual description field.
    description = ""

    # failover_ratio - (Optional) Ratio (0 to 1) of failed nodes before using the   backup pool (which must also be set).
    failover_ratio = ""

    # health_checks - (Optional) List of zero or one health check name or self_link. Only   legacy `google_compute_http_health_check` is supported.
    health_checks = ""

    # instances - (Optional) List of instances in the pool. They can be given as   URLs, or in the form of "zone/name". Note that the instances need not exist   at the time of target pool creation, so there is no need to use the   Terraform interpolators to create a dependency on the instances from the   target pool.
    instances = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # region - (Optional) Where the target pool resides. Defaults to project   region.
    region = ""

    # session_affinity - (Optional) How to distribute load. Options are "NONE" (no   affinity). "CLIENT\_IP" (hash of the source/dest addresses / ports), and   "CLIENT\_IP\_PROTO" also includes the protocol (default "NONE").
    session_affinity = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "session_affinity" - (Optional) How to distribute load. Options are "NONE" (no   affinity). "CLIENT\_IP" (hash of the source/dest addresses / ports), and   "CLIENT\_IP\_PROTO" also includes the protocol (default "NONE").
}
google-compute-target-pool.description:
Manages a Target Pool within GCE. This is a collection of instances used as
target of a network load balancer (Forwarding Rule). For more information see
[the official
documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/network/target-pools)
and [API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/targetPools).

google-compute-target-ssl-proxy.body:
resource "google_compute_target_ssl_proxy" "$1" {
    # ssl_certificates - (Required) The URLs of the SSL Certificate resources that   authenticate connections between users and load balancing.
    ssl_certificates = ""

    # backend_service - (Required) The URL of a Backend Service resource to receive the matched traffic.
    backend_service = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # proxy_header - (Optional) Type of proxy header to append before sending   data to the backend, either NONE or PROXY_V1 (default NONE).
    proxy_header = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of this resource. Changing this   forces a new resource to be created.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "proxy_id" - A unique ID assigned by GCE.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
}
google-compute-target-ssl-proxy.description:
Creates a target SSL proxy resource in GCE. For more information see
[the official
documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/ssl-ssl/) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/targetSslProxies).

google-compute-target-tcp-proxy.body:
resource "google_compute_target_tcp_proxy" "$1" {
    # backend_service - (Required) The URL of a Backend Service resource to receive the matched traffic.
    backend_service = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # proxy_header - (Optional) Type of proxy header to append before sending   data to the backend, either NONE or PROXY_V1 (default NONE).
    proxy_header = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of this resource. Changing this   forces a new resource to be created.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "proxy_id" - A unique ID assigned by GCE.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
}
google-compute-target-tcp-proxy.description:
Creates a target TCP proxy resource in GCE. For more information see
[the official
documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/tcp-ssl/tcp-proxy) and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/targetTcpProxies).

google-compute-url-map.body:
resource "google_compute_url_map" "$1" {
    # path - (Required) The path component of the URL being tested.
    path = ""

    # host - (Required) The host component of the URL being tested.
    host = ""

    # service - (Required) The backend service or backend bucket that should be matched by this test.
    service = ""

    # service - (Required) The backend service or backend bucket to use if any of the given paths match.
    service = ""

    # paths - (Required) The list of [paths](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/urlMaps#pathMatchers.pathRules.paths)   to match against.
    paths = ""

    # default_service - (Required) The backend service or backend bucket to use if none of the given paths match.
    default_service = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the `path_matcher` resource.
    name = ""

    # path_matcher - (Required) The name of the `path_matcher` to apply this host rule to.
    path_matcher = ""

    # hosts - (Required) - The list of [host patterns](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/urlMaps#hostRules.hosts) to match.
    hosts = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # default_service - (Required) The backend service or backend bucket to use when none of the given rules match.
    default_service = ""

    # description - (Optional) A brief description of this resource.
    description = ""

    # host_rule - (Optional) A list of host rules. Multiple blocks of this type are permitted. Structure is documented below.
    host_rule = ""

    # path_matcher - (Optional) A list of paths to match. Structure is documented below.
    path_matcher = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # test - (Optional) The test to perform.  Multiple blocks of this type are permitted. Structure is documented below.
    test = ""

    # description - (Optional) An optional description of the host rule.
    description = ""

    # description - (Optional) An optional description of the host rule.
    description = ""

    # path_rule - (Optional)  A list of path rules. Multiple blocks of this type are permitted. Structure is documented below.
    path_rule = ""

    # description - (Optional) An optional description of this test.
    description = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "fingerprint" - The unique fingerprint for this resource.
    # "map_id" - The GCE assigned ID of the resource.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
}
google-compute-url-map.description:
Manages a URL Map resource within GCE. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/http/url-map)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/latest/urlMaps).

google-compute-vpn-gateway.body:
resource "google_compute_vpn_gateway" "$1" {
    # network - (Required) The name or resource link to the network this VPN gateway   is accepting traffic for. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    network = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the resource.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    description = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region this gateway should sit in. If not specified,   the project region will be used. Changing this forces a new resource to be   created.
    region = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "region" - (Optional) The region this gateway should sit in. If not specified,   the project region will be used. Changing this forces a new resource to be   created.
}
google-compute-vpn-gateway.description:
Manages a VPN Gateway in the GCE network. For more info, read the
[documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/vpn).

google-compute-vpn-tunnel.body:
resource "google_compute_vpn_tunnel" "$1" {
    # target_vpn_gateway - (Required) A link to the VPN gateway sitting inside   GCE. Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    target_vpn_gateway = ""

    # shared_secret - (Required) A passphrase shared between the two VPN gateways.   Changing this forces a new resource to be created.
    shared_secret = ""

    # peer_ip - (Required) The VPN gateway sitting outside of GCE. Changing this   forces a new resource to be created.
    peer_ip = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource, required by GCE. Changing   this forces a new resource to be created.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the resource. Changing this forces   a new resource to be created.
    description = ""

    # ike_version - (Optional) Either version 1 or 2. Default is 2. Changing this   forces a new resource to be created.
    ike_version = ""

    # local_traffic_selector - (Optional) Specifies which CIDR ranges are   announced to the VPN peer. Mandatory if the VPN gateway is attached to a   custom subnetted network. Refer to Google documentation for more   information.
    local_traffic_selector = ""

    # remote_traffic_selector - (Optional) Specifies which CIDR ranges the VPN   tunnel can route to the remote side. Mandatory if the VPN gateway is attached to a   custom subnetted network. Refer to Google documentation for more   information.
    remote_traffic_selector = ""

    # router - (Optional) Name of a Cloud Router in the same region   to be used for dynamic routing. Refer to Google documentation for more   information.
    router = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region this tunnel should sit in. If not specified,   the project region will be used. Changing this forces a new resource to be   created.
    region = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "detailed_status" - Information about the status of the VPN tunnel.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
}
google-compute-vpn-tunnel.description:
Manages a VPN Tunnel to the GCE network. For more info, read the
[documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/vpn). ~> **Note:** All arguments including the `shared_secret` will be stored in the raw state as plain-text.
[Read more about sensitive data in state](/docs/state/sensitive-data.html).

google-container-cluster.body:
resource "google_container_cluster" "$1" {
    # username - (Required) The username to use for HTTP basic authentication when accessing   the Kubernetes master endpoint
    username = ""

    # username - (Required) The username to use for HTTP basic authentication when accessing   the Kubernetes master endpoint
    username = ""

    # password - (Required) The password to use for HTTP basic authentication when accessing   the Kubernetes master endpoint
    password = ""

    # daily_maintenance_window - (Required) Time window specified for daily maintenance operations.
    daily_maintenance_window = ""

    # zone - (Required) The zone that the master and the number of nodes specified   in `initial_node_count` should be created in.
    zone = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the cluster, unique within the project and   zone.
    name = ""

    # additional_zones - (Optional) The list of additional Google Compute Engine   locations in which the cluster's nodes should be located. If additional zones are   configured, the number of nodes specified in `initial_node_count` is created in   all specified zones.
    additional_zones = ""

    # addons_config - (Optional) The configuration for addons supported by Google   Container Engine. Structure is documented below.
    addons_config = ""

    # description - (Optional) Description of the cluster.
    description = ""

    # enable_kubernetes_alpha - (Optional) Whether to enable Kubernetes Alpha features for   this cluster. Note that when this option is enabled, the cluster cannot be upgraded   and will be automatically deleted after 30 days.
    enable_kubernetes_alpha = ""

    # enable_legacy_abac - (Optional) Whether the ABAC authorizer is enabled for this cluster.   When enabled, identities in the system, including service accounts, nodes, and controllers,   will have statically granted permissions beyond those provided by the RBAC configuration or IAM.
    enable_legacy_abac = ""

    # initial_node_count - (Optional) The number of nodes to create in this   cluster (not including the Kubernetes master). Must be set if `node_pool` is not set.
    initial_node_count = ""

    # logging_service - (Optional) The logging service that the cluster should   write logs to. Available options include `logging.googleapis.com` and   `none`. Defaults to `logging.googleapis.com`
    logging_service = ""

    # maintenance_policy - (Optional) The maintenance policy to use for the cluster. Structure is    documented below. 
    maintenance_policy = ""

    # master_auth - (Optional) The authentication information for accessing the   Kubernetes master. Structure is documented below.
    master_auth = ""

    # master_authorized_networks_config - (Optional) The desired configuration options   for master authorized networks. Omit the nested `cidr_blocks` attribute to disallow   external access (except the cluster node IPs, which GKE automatically whitelists).
    master_authorized_networks_config = ""

    # min_master_version - (Optional) The minimum version of the master. GKE   will auto-update the master to new versions, so this does not guarantee the   current master version--use the read-only `master_version` field to obtain that.   If unset, the cluster's version will be set by GKE to the version of the most recent   official release (which is not necessarily the latest version).
    min_master_version = ""

    # monitoring_service - (Optional) The monitoring service that the cluster   should write metrics to. Available options include   `monitoring.googleapis.com` and `none`. Defaults to   `monitoring.googleapis.com`
    monitoring_service = ""

    # network - (Optional) The name or self_link of the Google Compute Engine   network to which the cluster is connected.
    network = ""

    # node_config - (Optional) Parameters used in creating the cluster's nodes.   Structure is documented below.
    node_config = ""

    # node_pool - (Optional) List of node pools associated with this cluster.   See [google_container_node_pool](container_node_pool.html) for schema.
    node_pool = ""

    # node_version - (Optional) The Kubernetes version on the nodes. Must either be unset   or set to the same value as `min_master_version` on create. Defaults to the default   version set by GKE which is not necessarily the latest version.
    node_version = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # subnetwork - (Optional) The name of the Google Compute Engine subnetwork in   which the cluster's instances are launched.
    subnetwork = ""

    # horizontal_pod_autoscaling - (Optional) The status of the Horizontal Pod Autoscaling   addon, which increases or decreases the number of replica pods a replication controller   has based on the resource usage of the existing pods. It is enabled by default;   set `disabled = true` to disable.
    horizontal_pod_autoscaling = ""

    # http_load_balancing - (Optional) The status of the HTTP (L7) load balancing   controller addon, which makes it easy to set up HTTP load balancers for services in a   cluster. It is enabled by default; set `disabled = true` to disable.
    http_load_balancing = ""

    # kubernetes_dashboard - (Optional) The status of the Kubernetes Dashboard   add-on, which controls whether the Kubernetes Dashboard is enabled for this cluster.   It is enabled by default; set `disabled = true` to disable.
    kubernetes_dashboard = ""

    # kubernetes_dashboard - (Optional) The status of the Kubernetes Dashboard   add-on, which controls whether the Kubernetes Dashboard is enabled for this cluster.   It is enabled by default; set `disabled = true` to disable.
    kubernetes_dashboard = ""

    # cidr_blocks - (Optional) Defines up to 10 external networks that can access
    cidr_blocks = ""

    # cidr_block - (Optional) External network that can access Kubernetes master through HTTPS.   Must be specified in CIDR notation.
    cidr_block = ""

    # display_name - (Optional) Field for users to identify CIDR blocks.
    display_name = ""

    # disk_size_gb - (Optional) Size of the disk attached to each node, specified   in GB. The smallest allowed disk size is 10GB. Defaults to 100GB.
    disk_size_gb = ""

    # image_type - (Optional) The image type to use for this node.
    image_type = ""

    # labels - (Optional) The Kubernetes labels (key/value pairs) to be applied to each node.
    labels = ""

    # local_ssd_count - (Optional) The amount of local SSD disks that will be   attached to each cluster node. Defaults to 0.
    local_ssd_count = ""

    # machine_type - (Optional) The name of a Google Compute Engine machine type.   Defaults to `n1-standard-1`.
    machine_type = ""

    # metadata - (Optional) The metadata key/value pairs assigned to instances in   the cluster.
    metadata = ""

    # min_cpu_platform - (Optional) Minimum CPU platform to be used by this instance.   The instance may be scheduled on the specified or newer CPU platform. Applicable   values are the friendly names of CPU platforms, such as `Intel Haswell`. See the   [official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instances/specify-min-cpu-platform)   for more information.
    min_cpu_platform = ""

    # oauth_scopes - (Optional) The set of Google API scopes to be made available   on all of the node VMs under the "default" service account. These can be   either FQDNs, or scope aliases. The following scopes are necessary to ensure   the correct functioning of the cluster: `compute-rw` (`https://www.googleapis.com/auth/compute`)
    oauth_scopes = ""

    # oauth_scopes - (Optional) The set of Google API scopes to be made available   on all of the node VMs under the "default" service account. These can be   either FQDNs, or scope aliases. The following scopes are necessary to ensure   the correct functioning of the cluster: `compute-rw` (`https://www.googleapis.com/auth/compute`)
    oauth_scopes = ""

    # oauth_scopes - (Optional) The set of Google API scopes to be made available   on all of the node VMs under the "default" service account. These can be   either FQDNs, or scope aliases. The following scopes are necessary to ensure   the correct functioning of the cluster: `compute-rw` (`https://www.googleapis.com/auth/compute`)
    oauth_scopes = ""

    # monitoring - (Optional) `monitoring` (`https://www.googleapis.com/auth/monitoring`),
    monitoring = ""

    # oauth_scopes - (Optional) The set of Google API scopes to be made available   on all of the node VMs under the "default" service account. These can be   either FQDNs, or scope aliases. The following scopes are necessary to ensure   the correct functioning of the cluster: `compute-rw` (`https://www.googleapis.com/auth/compute`)
    oauth_scopes = ""

    # oauth_scopes - (Optional) The set of Google API scopes to be made available   on all of the node VMs under the "default" service account. These can be   either FQDNs, or scope aliases. The following scopes are necessary to ensure   the correct functioning of the cluster: `compute-rw` (`https://www.googleapis.com/auth/compute`)
    oauth_scopes = ""

    # preemptible - (Optional) A boolean that represents whether or not the underlying node VMs   are preemptible. See the [official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/container-engine/docs/preemptible-vm)   for more information. Defaults to false.
    preemptible = ""

    # service_account - (Optional) The service account to be used by the Node VMs.   If not specified, the "default" service account is used.
    service_account = ""

    # tags - (Optional) The list of instance tags applied to all nodes. Tags are used to identify   valid sources or targets for network firewalls.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "endpoint" - The IP address of this cluster's Kubernetes master.
    # "instance_group_urls" - List of instance group URLs which have been assigned   to the cluster.
    # "maintenance_policy.0.daily_maintenance_window.0.duration" - Duration of the time window, automatically chosen to be   smallest possible in the given scenario.     Duration will be in [RFC3339](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt) format "PTnHnMnS".
    # "master_auth.0.client_certificate" - Base64 encoded public certificate   used by clients to authenticate to the cluster endpoint.
    # "master_auth.0.client_key" - Base64 encoded private key used by clients   to authenticate to the cluster endpoint.
    # "master_auth.0.cluster_ca_certificate" - Base64 encoded public certificate   that is the root of trust for the cluster.
    # "master_version" - The current version of the master in the cluster. This may   be different than the "min_master_version" set in the config if the master   has been updated by GKE.
}
google-container-cluster.description:
Creates a GKE cluster. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/container-engine/docs/clusters)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/container-engine/reference/rest/v1/projects.zones.clusters). ~> **Note:** All arguments including the username and password will be stored in the raw state as plain-text.
[Read more about sensitive data in state](/docs/state/sensitive-data.html).

google-container-node-pool.body:
resource "google_container_node_pool" "$1" {
    # max_node_count - (Required) Maximum number of nodes in the NodePool. Must be >= min_node_count.
    max_node_count = ""

    # min_node_count - (Required) Minimum number of nodes in the NodePool. Must be >=1 and   <= `max_node_count`.
    min_node_count = ""

    # cluster - (Required) The cluster to create the node pool for.
    cluster = ""

    # zone - (Required) The zone in which the cluster resides.
    zone = ""

    # autoscaling - (Optional) Configuration required by cluster autoscaler to adjust   the size of the node pool to the current cluster usage. Structure is documented below.
    autoscaling = ""

    # initial_node_count - (Optional) (Deprecated, Optional) The initial node count for the pool.   Use `node_count` instead.
    initial_node_count = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the node pool. If left blank, Terraform will   auto-generate a unique name.
    name = ""

    # name_prefix - (Optional) Creates a unique name for the node pool beginning   with the specified prefix. Conflicts with `name`.
    name_prefix = ""

    # node_config - (Optional) The node configuration of the pool. See   [google_container_cluster](container_cluster.html for schema.
    node_config = ""

    # node_count - (Optional) The number of nodes per instance group.
    node_count = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which to create the node pool. If blank,   the provider-configured project will be used.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
google-container-node-pool.description:
Manages a Node Pool resource within GKE. For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/container-engine/docs/node-pools)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/container-engine/reference/rest/v1/projects.zones.clusters.nodePools).

google-dataproc-cluster.body:
resource "google_dataproc_cluster" "$1" {
    # script - (Required) The script to be executed during initialization of the cluster.  The script must be a GCS file with a gs:// prefix.
    script = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the cluster, unique within the project and
    name = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the `cluster` will exist. If it 	is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which the cluster and associated nodes will be created in.  Defaults to `global`.
    region = ""

    # labels - (Optional) (Optional, Computed) The list of labels (key/value pairs) to be applied to  instances in the cluster. GCP generates some itself including `goog-dataproc-cluster-name`  which is the name of the cluster.
    labels = ""

    # cluster_config - (Optional) Allows you to configure various aspects of the cluster.  Structure defined below.
    cluster_config = ""

    # staging_bucket - (Optional) The Cloud Storage staging bucket used to stage files,  such as Hadoop jars, between client machines and the cluster.  Note: If you don't explicitly specify a `staging_bucket`  then GCP will auto create / assign one for you. However, you are not guaranteed  an auto generated bucket which is solely dedicated to your cluster; it may be shared  with other clusters in the same region/zone also choosing to use the auto generation  option.
    staging_bucket = ""

    # delete_autogen_bucket - (Optional) If this is set to true, upon destroying the cluster,  if no explicit `staging_bucket` was specified (i.e. an auto generated bucket was relied  upon) then this auto generated bucket will also be deleted as part of the cluster destroy.  By default this is set to false.
    delete_autogen_bucket = ""

    # gce_cluster_config - (Optional) Common config settings for resources of Google Compute Engine cluster  instances, applicable to all instances in the cluster. Structure defined below.
    gce_cluster_config = ""

    # master_config - (Optional) The Google Compute Engine config settings for the master instances  in a cluster.. Structure defined below.
    master_config = ""

    # worker_config - (Optional) The Google Compute Engine config settings for the worker instances  in a cluster.. Structure defined below.
    worker_config = ""

    # preemptible_worker_config - (Optional) The Google Compute Engine config settings for the additional (aka  preemptible) instancesin a cluster. Structure defined below.
    preemptible_worker_config = ""

    # software_config - (Optional) The config settings for software inside the cluster.  Structure defined below.
    software_config = ""

    # initialization_action - (Optional) Commands to execute on each node after config is completed.  You can specify multiple versions of these. Structure defined below.
    initialization_action = ""

    # zone - (Optional) (Optional, Computed) The GCP zone where your data is stored and used (i.e. where 	the master and the worker nodes will be created in). If `region` is set to 'global' (default) 	then `zone` is mandatory, otherwise GCP is able to make use of [Auto Zone Placement](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/auto-zone) 	to determine this automatically for you. 	Note: This setting additionally determines and restricts 	which computing resources are available for use with other configs such as 	`cluster_config.master_config.machine_type` and `cluster_config.worker_config.machine_type`.
    zone = ""

    # network - (Optional) (Optional, Computed) The name or self_link of the Google Compute Engine 	network to the cluster will be part of. Conflicts with `subnetwork`. 	If neither is specified, this defaults to the "default" network.
    network = ""

    # subnetwork - (Optional) The name or self_link of the Google Compute Engine  subnetwork the cluster will be part of. Conflicts with `network`.
    subnetwork = ""

    # service_account - (Optional) The service account to be used by the Node VMs. 	If not specified, the "default" service account is used.
    service_account = ""

    # service_scopes - (Optional) (Optional, Computed) The set of Google API scopes to be made available 	on all of the node VMs under the `service_account` specified. These can be 	either FQDNs, or scope aliases. The following scopes are necessary to ensure 	the correct functioning of the cluster: `useraccounts-ro` (`https://www.googleapis.com/auth/cloud.useraccounts.readonly`)
    service_scopes = ""

    # service_scopes - (Optional) (Optional, Computed) The set of Google API scopes to be made available 	on all of the node VMs under the `service_account` specified. These can be 	either FQDNs, or scope aliases. The following scopes are necessary to ensure 	the correct functioning of the cluster: `useraccounts-ro` (`https://www.googleapis.com/auth/cloud.useraccounts.readonly`)
    service_scopes = ""

    # service_scopes - (Optional) (Optional, Computed) The set of Google API scopes to be made available 	on all of the node VMs under the `service_account` specified. These can be 	either FQDNs, or scope aliases. The following scopes are necessary to ensure 	the correct functioning of the cluster: `useraccounts-ro` (`https://www.googleapis.com/auth/cloud.useraccounts.readonly`)
    service_scopes = ""

    # service_scopes - (Optional) (Optional, Computed) The set of Google API scopes to be made available 	on all of the node VMs under the `service_account` specified. These can be 	either FQDNs, or scope aliases. The following scopes are necessary to ensure 	the correct functioning of the cluster: `useraccounts-ro` (`https://www.googleapis.com/auth/cloud.useraccounts.readonly`)
    service_scopes = ""

    # tags - (Optional) The list of instance tags applied to instances in the cluster.  Tags are used to identify valid sources or targets for network firewalls.
    tags = ""

    # num_instances - (Optional) `num_instances`- (Optional, Computed) Specifies the number of master nodes to create.  If not specified, GCP will default to a predetermined computed value (currently 1).
    num_instances = ""

    # machine_type - (Optional) (Optional, Computed) The name of a Google Compute Engine machine type  to create for the master. If not specified, GCP will default to a predetermined  computed value (currently `n1-standard-4`).
    machine_type = ""

    # num_instances - (Optional) `num_instances`- (Optional, Computed) Specifies the number of worker nodes to create.  If not specified, GCP will default to a predetermined computed value (currently 2).  There is currently a beta feature which allows you to run a  [Single Node Cluster](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/single-node-clusters).  In order to take advantage of this you need to set  `"dataproc:dataproc.allow.zero.workers" = "true"` in  `cluster_config.software_config.properties`
    num_instances = ""

    # machine_type - (Optional) (Optional, Computed) The name of a Google Compute Engine machine type  to create for the worker nodes. If not specified, GCP will default to a predetermined  computed value (currently `n1-standard-4`).
    machine_type = ""

    # boot_disk_size_gb - (Optional) (Optional, Computed) Size of the primary disk attached to each worker node, specified in GB. The smallest allowed disk size is 10GB. GCP will default to a predetermined computed value if not set (currently 500GB). Note: If SSDs are not 	attached, it also contains the HDFS data blocks and Hadoop working directories.
    boot_disk_size_gb = ""

    # num_local_ssds - (Optional) The amount of local SSD disks that will be 	attached to each worker cluster node. Defaults to 0.
    num_local_ssds = ""

    # num_local_ssds - (Optional) The amount of local SSD disks that will be 	attached to each worker cluster node. Defaults to 0.
    num_local_ssds = ""

    # num_instances - (Optional) Specifies the number of preemptible nodes to create.  Defaults to 0.
    num_instances = ""

    # disk_config - (Optional) Disk Config `boot_disk_size_gb` - (Optional, Computed) Size of the primary disk attached to each preemptible worker node, specified in GB. The smallest allowed disk size is 10GB. GCP will default to a predetermined computed value if not set (currently 500GB). Note: If SSDs are not 	attached, it also contains the HDFS data blocks and Hadoop working directories.
    disk_config = ""

    # disk_config - (Optional) Disk Config `boot_disk_size_gb` - (Optional, Computed) Size of the primary disk attached to each preemptible worker node, specified in GB. The smallest allowed disk size is 10GB. GCP will default to a predetermined computed value if not set (currently 500GB). Note: If SSDs are not 	attached, it also contains the HDFS data blocks and Hadoop working directories.
    disk_config = ""

    # image_version - (Optional) this controls the sets of software versions  installed onto the nodes when you create clusters. If not specified, defaults to the  latest version. For a list of valid versions see  [Cloud Dataproc versions](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/dataproc-versions)
    image_version = ""

    # override_properties - (Optional) A list of override and additional properties (key/value pairs)  used to modify various aspects of the common configuration files used when creating  a cluster. For a list of valid properties please see [Cluster properties](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/cluster-properties)
    override_properties = ""

    # timeout_sec - (Optional) (Optional, Computed) The maximum duration (in seconds) which `script` is  allowed to take to execute its action. GCP will default to a predetermined  computed value if not set (currently 300).
    timeout_sec = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "cluster_config.master_config.instance_names" - List of master instance names which  have been assigned to the cluster.
    # "cluster_config.worker_config.instance_names" - List of worker instance names which have been assigned 	to the cluster.
    # "cluster_config.preemptible_worker_config.instance_names" - List of preemptible instance names which have been assigned 	to the cluster.
    # "cluster_config.bucket" - The name of the cloud storage bucket ultimately used to house the staging data  for the cluster. If "staging_bucket" is specified, it will contain this value, otherwise  it will be the auto generated name.
    # "cluster_config.software_config.properties" - A list of the properties used to set the daemon config files.  This will include any values supplied by the user via "cluster_config.software_config.override_properties"
}
google-dataproc-cluster.description:
Manages a Cloud Dataproc cluster resource within GCP. For more information see
[the official dataproc documentation](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/). !> **Warning:** Due to limitations of the API, all arguments except
`labels`,`cluster_config.worker_config.num_instances` and `cluster_config.preemptible_worker_config.num_instances` are non-updateable. Changing others will cause recreation of the
whole cluster!

google-datasource-client-config.description: Use this data source to access the configuration of the Google Cloud provider.

google-datasource-compute-instance-group.body:
data "google_compute_instance_group" "$1" {
    # zone - (Required) The zone of the instance group.
    zone = ""

    zone = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the instance group.
    name = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "description" - Textual description of the instance group.
    # "instances" - List of instances in the group.
    # "named_port" - List of named ports in the group. 
    # "network" - The URL of the network the instance group is in.

}

google-datasource-compute-lb-ip-ranges.description: Use this data source to access IP ranges in your firewall rules. https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/load-balancing/health-checks#health_check_source_ips_and_firewall_rules

google-datasource-compute-network.body:
data "google_compute_network" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the network.
    name = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "network" - The network name or resource link to the parent   network of this network. 
    # "description" - Description of this network.
    # "gateway_ipv4" - The IP address of the gateway.
    # "subnetworks_self_links" - the list of subnetworks which belong to the network

google-datasource-compute-network.description: Get a network within GCE from its name.

google-datasource-compute-subnetwork.body:
data "google_compute_subnetwork" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) The name of the subnetwork.
    name = ""

    # project - (Optional) The project in which the resource belongs. If it   is not provided, the provider project is used.
    project = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region this subnetwork has been created in. If   unspecified, this defaults to the region configured in the provider.
    region = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "network" - The network name or resource link to the parent   network of this subnetwork.
    # "description" - Description of this subnetwork.
    # "ip_cidr_range" - The IP address range that machines in this   network are assigned to, represented as a CIDR block.
    # "gateway_address" - The IP address of the gateway.
    # "private_ip_google_access" - Whether the VMs in this subnet   can access Google services without assigned external IP   addresses.
    # "secondary_ip_range" - An array of configurations for secondary IP ranges for   VM instances contained in this subnetwork. Structure is documented below.
    # "self_link" - The URI of the created resource.
    # "range_name" - The name associated with this subnetwork secondary range, used   when adding an alias IP range to a VM instance.
    # "ip_cidr_range" - The range of IP addresses belonging to this subnetwork   secondary range.
}
google-datasource-compute-subnetwork.description: Get a subnetwork within GCE from its name and region.

google-datasource-compute-zones.body:
data "google_compute_zones" "$1" {
    # region - (Optional) - Region from which to list available zones. Defaults to region declared in the provider.
    region = ""

    # status - (Optional) - Allows to filter list of zones based on their current status. Status can be either `UP` or `DOWN`.

}

google-datasource-container-versions.body:
data "google_container_engine_versions" "$1" {
    # zone - (Optional) Zone to list available cluster versions for. Should match the zone the cluster will be deployed in.
    zone = ""

    # project - (Optional) ID of the project to list available cluster versions for. Should match the project the cluster will be deployed to.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "valid_master_versions" - A list of versions available in the given zone for use with master instances.
    # "valid_node_versions" - A list of versions available in the given zone for use with node instances.
    # "latest_master_version" - The latest version available in the given zone for use with master instances.
    # "latest_node_version" - The latest version available in the given zone for use with node instances.
}

google-datasource-dns-managed-zone.body:
data "google_dns_managed_zone" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource.
    name = ""

    # project - (Optional) ID of the project for the Google Cloud DNS zone.
    project = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "dns_name" - The DNS name of this zone, e.g. "terraform.io".
    # "description" - A textual description field.
    # "name_servers" - The list of nameservers that will be authoritative for this   domain. Use NS records to redirect from your DNS provider to these names,   thus making Google Cloud DNS authoritative for this zone.
}
google-datasource-dns-managed-zone.description:
Provides access to a zone's attributes within Google Cloud DNS.
For more information see
[the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/dns/zones/)
and
[API](https://cloud.google.com/dns/api/v1/managedZones). data "google_dns_managed_zone" "env_dns_zone" {
  name        = "qa-zone"
}

resource "google_dns_record_set" "dns" {
  name = "my-address.${data.google_dns_managed_zone.env_dns_zone.dns_name}"
  type = "TXT"
  ttl  = 300

  managed_zone = "${data.google_dns_managed_zone.env_dns_zone.name}"

  rrdatas = ["test"]
}
